article: In 1970, at the age of 35, my father was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease. There was not much _ done at that time and my father had to rely on the medication and treatment that were _ at that time. But one thing was _ , my father was not a quitter. He was a teacher who _ children with special educational needs in Chicago Public High School. Every day we would hear _ about "his kids". These "kids" did not usually _ my sister and I. One day, my father arrived at his school and walked up the _ for his first period. He was having a very _ day because the disease was really taking everything out of him. He _ once and bruised his knee but he still kept going. _ did he know that someone was watching. As the day _ his steps began to get a little lighter. At the end of the day, he was about to leave _ a young girl entered his office. He had met her in the hallway but she was not one of his _ . He asked what he could do for her and she said, "I just wanted to thank you for _ my life." He looked at her and couldn't figure out what he had done. She then went on _ . "When I got up this morning, I felt as if I was at the end of my _ and ready to kill myself. But when I saw you trying to go up the stairs and then you fell, I felt _ and the feeling of sadness just kept getting _ . And now you are walking as _ as ever. It's really true that everything will get better as the days go on."
